title: Angular impulse - pivoting mallet strikes bumper

content.question: A mallet rotates about a pivot near one end of its handle and is moving clockwise with an angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> as it strikes a small, stationary rubber bumper, as shown in the figure. Immediately after the impact, the mallet is rotating counterclockwise about the pivot with an angular speed <math alttext="the fraction omega sub 0 over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. The handle of the mallet has length <math alttext="lowercase l sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 0 equals one third m sub 0, end sub, lowercase l sub 0, end sub, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msup><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>0</mn></msub><mn>2</mn></msup></math> about the pivot. The head of the mallet is small compared to the length of the handle, has the same mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> as the handle, and is located a distance <math alttext="lowercase l sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mo>ℓ</mo><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from the pivot. If the mallet is in contact with the bumper for an amount of time <math alttext="delta t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>t</mi></math>, what is the magnitude of the average force that the mallet exerts on the rubber bumper during the contact time?
